Title: python - Why does 1+++2 = 3? - Stack Overflow

How many ever + I put in between, it is printing 3 as the answer. Please can anyone explain this behavior And for 1--2 it is printing 3 and for 1---2 it is printing -1     pythonevaluationoperator-precedence          Share   Improve this question                        Follow                          edited Dec 19, 2018 at 17:44      pushkin  9,5351515 gold badges5151 silver badges9595 bronze badges                asked Jan 22, 2009 at 17:41      udpsuniludpsunil  1,36522 gold badges1616 silver badges2929 bronze badges        3           So does that mean there are no increment operators in python?  – udpsunil  Jan 22, 2009 at 17:52       2     To increment a variable i in python: i += 1  – Greg Hewgill  Jan 22, 2009 at 17:56       6     -1: The question makes a huge number of assumptions about ++ and --; things which are answered directly in python.org/doc/2.5.2/ref/expressions.html  – S.Lott  Jan 22, 2009 at 23:12       Add a comment  |                                                         6 Answers                                     6                   Sorted by:                       Reset to default                                      Highest score (default)                                               Trending (recent votes count more)                                               Date modified (newest first)                                               Date created (oldest first)                                                 63                           Your expression is the same as: 1+(+(+2))  Any numeric expression can be preceded by - to make it negative, or + to do nothing (the option is present for symmetry). With negative signs: 1-(-(2)) = 1-(-2)          = 1+2          = 3  and 1-(-(-2)) = 1-(2)           = -1  I see you clarified your question to say that you come from a C background. In Python, there are no increment operators like ++ and -- in C, which was probably the source of your confusion. To increment or decrement a variable i or j in Python use this style: i += 1 j -= 1          Share   Improve this answer                        Follow                          edited Sep 29, 2015 at 17:23      hjpotter92  78.5k3636 gold badges142142 silver badges182182 bronze badges                answered Jan 22, 2009 at 17:46      Greg HewgillGreg Hewgill  950k183183 gold badges11471147 silver badges12831283 bronze badges        1       3     Btw: That was a design decision from the Python creators. It should exactly prohibit writing such indetermined code like i+++j.  – Boldewyn  Jul 7, 2009 at 8:17       Add a comment  |                                15                           The extra +'s are not incrementors (like ++a or a++ in c++).  They are just showing that the number is positive. There is no such ++ operator.  There is a unary + operator and a unary - operator though.  The unary + operator has no effect on its argument. The unary - operator negates its operator or mulitplies it by -1.  +1  -> 1 ++1  -> 1 This is the same as +(+(1))    1+++2  -> 3 Because it's the same as 1 + (+(+(2)) Likewise you can do --1 to mean - (-1)  which is +1.   --1  -> 1 For completeness there is no * unary opeartor.  So *1 is an error.  But there is a **  operator which is power of, it takes 2 arguments.   2**3  -> 8         Share   Improve this answer                        Follow                          edited Jan 22, 2009 at 17:58                     answered Jan 22, 2009 at 17:47      Brian R. BondyBrian R. Bondy  339k124124 gold badges595595 silver badges636636 bronze badges               Add a comment  |                            4                           1+(+(+2)) = 3 1 - (-2) = 3 1 - (-(-2)) = -1         Share   Improve this answer                        Follow                                  answered Jan 22, 2009 at 17:46      alexwoodalexwood  61222 gold badges77 silver badges1414 bronze badges               Add a comment  |                                4                           Trying Unary Plus and Unary minus:  The unary - (minus) operator yields the negation of its numeric argument. The unary + (plus) operator yields its numeric argument unchanged.  >>> +2 2 >>> ++2 2 >>> +++2 2 >>> -2 -2 >>> --2 2 >>> ---2 -2 >>> 1+(++2) 3          Share   Improve this answer                        Follow                          edited Jun 20, 2020 at 9:12      CommunityBot  111 silver badge                answered Jan 22, 2009 at 17:47      gimelgimel  83.3k1010 gold badges7676 silver badges104104 bronze badges        2           but I am getting the result 3 for 1+++++++++++++2 also  – udpsunil  Jan 22, 2009 at 17:53       1     No sweat: 1+(+(+(+(+(+(+(+(+(+(+(+(+2)))))))))))) 12 +'s are unary - see Greg Hewgill's reply.  – gimel  Jan 23, 2009 at 8:09       Add a comment  |                            1                           I believe it's being parsed as, the first + as a binary operation (add), and the rest as unary operations (make positive).   1 + (+(+2))          Share   Improve this answer                        Follow                                  answered Jan 22, 2009 at 17:47      James CurranJames Curran  102k3737 gold badges181181 silver badges258258 bronze badges               Add a comment  |                            1                           Think it as 1 + (+1*(+1*2))). The first + is operator and following plus signs are sign of second operand (= 2). Just like 1---2 is same as 1 - -(-(2)) or 1- (-1*(-1*(2))         Share   Improve this answer                        Follow                          edited Jan 22, 2009 at 18:34                     answered Jan 22, 2009 at 17:47      Juha SyrjäläJuha Syrjälä  33.4k3131 gold badges131131 silver badges183183 bronze badges               Add a comment  |                                                 Your Answer                                                  Thanks for contributing an answer to Stack Overflow!Please be sure to answer the question.
